column1: In Gunadasa v. Attorney-General and Others [1989] 2 SLR 130, 133-134 it was held by Justice

column2: "...It has been said by Lord Denning in the case of Kanda vs. Government of
Malaya  that,  "If  the  right  to  be  heard  is  to  be  a  real  right  which  is  worth
anything,  it  must  carry  with  it  a  right  in  the  accused  man  to  know  the  case
which is made against him. He must know what evidence has been given and
what statements have been made affecting him and then he must be given a

column1: fair opportunity to correct or contradict them."

column2: "Hence  the  failure to  give  to the petitioner  a fair  opportunity  to  "correct  or

column1: contradict"  the  said  witnesses  when  they  gave  evidence,

column2: occasioned a violation of the principle of natural justice, that a man's defence
must  always  be  fairly  heard.  The  non  observation  of  the  said  principle  of
natural  justice  would  consequently  amount  to  an  error  on  the  face  of  the

column1: record, which would attract the remedy of Writ of Certiorari"
